bioghist.p: Beatrice Schenk de Regniers (1914-2000) was a writer of children's books. She was trained in social work and held a Master's in Education from Winnetka Graduate Teachers' College. During the 1950s she began writing for children, and The Giant Story (illustrated by Maurice Sendak) appeared in 1953. In addition, she wrote articles and stories for adults. In 1961, she became the first editor of Scholastic Book's "Lucky Book Club." Twenty years later she retired to write for the theater. Her first production appeared in 1986, based on her book Everyone Is Good for Something. She wrote more than 50 children's books, some using the pseudonym Tamara Kitt, and was the recipient of many awards and honors.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of manuscripts, notes, and correspondence of Beatrice de Regniers. Documentation is present for The Little Girl and Her Mother, Willy O'Dwyer Jumped in the Fire, May I Bring a Friend?, and The Abe Lincoln Joke Book. Materials include production notes and correspondence with editors; annotated manuscripts; galley proofs; dummies; blurb text; and notes by the author on the creation of Willy O'Dwyer.
